awd_titl_txt: Forces and molecules that shape tissue across the evolution of Drosophilid species
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals exhibit an amazing variety of shapes and forms, yet the variations have evolved by modifying fundamental developmental processes shared by all animals.  For example, a human hand, a bat's wing, and a whale's flipper all arise from a common set of instructions that direct the activities of highly conserved molecules that regulate cellular structure, signaling, and adhesion.  Although these processes that give tissues and organs their shape are essential to multicellular life, surprisingly little is known about the underlying mechanisms that regulate the shapes of tissues. This project investigates the physical forces, cellular behaviors, and molecular regulators that determine tissue shape by exploring the formation of eggshell appendages in Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies) and related Dipteran (fly) species.  This work develops a novel technique to measure cellular forces and generates new genomic and gene expression data from across a variety of unexplored species.  Additionally, this project brings teachers and students into the laboratory to carry out independent research projects, learn firsthand about the logic and methods of science, and develop STEM lesson plans related to the mechanisms underlying, and evolution of tissue shape.

Epithelial tubes are important features of multi-cellular life and form the framework controlling the shape of many internal organs. While the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying tube formation are heavily studied, the mechanisms controlling tube morphology are less well understood. This project uses the dorsal appendages (DAs) of the Drosophila eggshell as a system in which to study the control of tube shape. The DA system is an ideal system in which to address questions of tube formation both because the fundamental mechanisms underlying patterning and the initiation of tube formation have already been heavily studied, and because eggshell appendages vary considerably in shape from one Drosophilid species to another allowing comparative approaches. Within the context of DA formation, the investigators measure the pattern of physical forces exerted by follicle cells on the extracellular matrix, and test whether these forces at the basal surface predict the extent of tube elongation and overall tube geometry. The role of apical cell-shape changes on tube morphology, are also being examined with a special focus on the roles of the motor protein, myosin and the polarity protein, Par3 (Bazooka in flies). Finally, the group is profiling transcriptional differences between species with unique appendage morphologies, with the aim of identifying the molecular changes that facilitated the evolution of shape.  This work reveals and describes the forces that drive changes in organ shape and tissue morphogenesis. Furthermore the project provides hands-on opportunities for teachers and students to be involved in basic research in genetics, biomechanics and development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Shape is important in biology.  A giraffe’s long neck, a whale’s flippers, or a hummingbird’s wing all fit form to function.  Our organs also take on specific shapes to optimize their performance.  For example, the lungs create branched structures to maximize surface area for gas exchange, and the heart forms interconnected chambers for pumping blood. 

 

A common feature of many organs is that they are made up of tubes.  Remarkably, organs that have the same general function can have different arrangements or shapes of tubes depending on the species.  For example, the mouse lung has a different pattern of tube branching than the human lung.

 

We are studying the formation of tubular organs in the model system Drosophila melanogaster (the fruit fly), which has elegant genetic and molecular tools.  Fruit flies produce eggs with tubular eggshell appendages that are easy to image as they develop and grow.  Many of the genes that control formation of these structures are known and are shared in humans.  We identified several other Drosophilid (fruit fly) species that have differently shaped and geometrically arranged eggshell structures (Image One).  By comparing the processes by which these tubes form and by exploring the underlying genetics that regulates their synthesis, we can learn how different tissue morphologies evolve.

 

Our first step in characterizing these other species was to sequence their genomes.  This information let us identify the genes in those species that are counterparts to the previously characterized genes of Drosophila melanogaster.  In one case, we were able to completely assemble the genes in their order along the chromosomes (Image Two).  While the genes generally remain on the same chromosomes in C. procnemis as they are in D. melanogaster, gene order tends to be maintained in only small blocks, with those blocks significantly rearranged within the chromosomes.  Such a comprehensive framework is a useful resource for future genetic studies.

 

Using the genomic sequence information combined with further experiments, we compared which genes were turned on, and to what degree they were expressed, during tube formation in different species (Image Three).  These studies helped us identify differences between species that might contribute to different tube morphologies.

 

We also identified several new genes that are important for tube formation in Drosophila melanogaster and began to characterize their cellular functions in detail (Image Four A).  Based on our knowledge of how tubes form in Drosophila melanogaster, we examined the localization of key proteins in the developing tubes of the other species.  We discovered a new mechanism for cells to orient themselves in a tissue (Image Four B) and found that this mechanism creates multiple tubes from a single patch of cells in a related species, Scaptodrosophila lebanonensis. 

Using our experimental system, we introduced students and teachers to fundamental concepts in genomics, developmental biology, and evolution, and to basic mathematics that describes features of tissue morphogenesis.  At the University of Washington, we developed a new summer program that brought high school students into the lab to conduct independent research (Image Five).  At the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, we worked with an existing summer research program (STARS) to mentor a middle school science teacher, who gained hands-on lab experience and developed related curriculum for her classrooms (Image Six).

Through our work, we are uncovering highly conserved developmental events that control organ formation in animals.  We are also exposing youth to the methods and logic of science, skills that will aid them in their scientific pursuits and in many other endeavors.
